chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a lesion?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The key question to answer is whether the lesion could be a malignant melanoma.
  • Perform a history and examination to assess the possibility of melanoma. Examine the lesion in good light.
    • Pigmented lesions which 'stand out from the crowd' because they are different (the 'Ugly Duckling sign') are a cause for concern, especially if they are changing.
    • A dermatoscope can be used to examine skin lesions and may more accurately distinguish between benign and malignant lesions, but this should only be done by a primary healthcare professional who has had adequate training in its use.
  • Use the Weighted 7-point checklist for assessment of pigmented skin lesions, and to determine referral.
    • Major features of the lesion (2 points each):
      • Change in size.
      • Irregular shape or border.
      • Irregular colour.
    • Minor features of the lesion (1 point each):
      • Largest diameter 7 mm or more.
      • Inflammation.
      • Oozing or crusting of the lesion.
      • Change in sensation (including itch).
    • Suspicion is greater for lesions scoring 3 points or more. However, if there are strong concerns about cancer, any one feature is adequate to prompt urgent referral under the 2-week rule.
    • The following risk factors increase the risk of melanoma and should be factored at the time of assessment: family history of melanoma, personal history of melanoma, immunosuppression, excessive UV exposure including tanning beds. 
  • Examine other areas.
    • Inspect the rest of the skin for suspicious pigmented lesions or dysplastic naevi.
    • Palpate major lymph nodes in the regional drainage area if the lesion is suspicious of melanoma.

Evidence on self-examination for early melanoma detection

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
There is evidence from several studies comparing the sensitivity and specificity of the ABCD(E) rule and 7-point checklist (see evidence section). 

However, [NICE, 2015a] recommends using the weighted 7 point checklist for the identification of lesions which should be referred urgently using the suspected cancer pathway referral. The person should receive an appointment within 2 weeks and assessed by a competent professional. NICE also suggests the referral of people if dermoscopy suggests melanoma or if there is a pigmented or non-pigmented lesion suspicious of nodular melanoma. 

Dermoscopy

  • A dermatoscope is a hand-held light magnifier which can be used to visualize subsurface structures of a lesion, such as dots, streaks, veils, and networks, which can help to diagnose pigmented (or suspected pigmented) lesions [Rigel et al, 2010].
  • Guidelines on Improving outcomes for people with skin tumours including melanoma from the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence acknowledge that the dermatoscope is an important diagnostic aid that can be used to examine skin lesions and help to distinguish benign from malignant pigmented lesions [NICE, 2006; NICE, 2015a; NICE, 2016b].
